Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Digital soil and yield mapping with an optimized sampling design to provide accurate, rapid, and inexpensive maps for farm managers
Award.AbstractNarration: The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to understand the benefits of inexpensive and high-quality soil fertility and yield maps. Soil testing helps farmers to determine the amount of fertilizer needed for plants. In 2017, total agricultural land in Iowa was 30.5 million acres, and the average farm size was 351 acres. If all farm managers took samples based on the commonly used sampling design, they would spend over $291 million. With the new sampling design, farmers in Iowa may save close to $129 million (44%). During participation in the ISU I-Corps Site program, a key customer discovery finding was that farmers need these more accurate and less expensive maps compared to existing ones in order to fertilize their crops effectively, but without waste. <br/><br/>This I-Corps project will help to determine if farmers are interested in an alternative sampling design, which can provide low cost analysis of field variations. The technology will have the ability to supply precise management zones from accurate soil maps. The technology will create soil maps with relatively fine resolution (9 sq. meters) compared to the existing maps (2.5 acres). Preliminary results show that kriging can produce a soil map with 9 sq. meters; however, the accuracy of kriging maps (R2 = 0.1) with small sample sizes is remarkably smaller than the proposed maps (R2 = 0.53-0.61). Thus, the nutrient recommendations will remain effective while the costs decrease compared to the current methods (block and kriging).<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our technology aims to deliver a scalable digital soil map solution that meets the demands of modern commercial agriculture. Agronomists and growers (our end-users) use various tools to balance economic return/profitability and environmental externalities. Our engagement with the National I-Corps revealed that end-users actively seek to use higher quality maps to base their annual decision-making on; however, the tools available to them do not simultaneously deliver on accuracy and resolution. Our findings show that our innovation can decrease the risk of overapplying and underapplying fertilizer for growers by producing high-quality soil fertility maps. Doing so helps growers to apply the right amount of fertilizer in the right place.

High-quality soil information is a fundamental driver of better crop management, which has the potential to lower food costs and improve environmental sustainability. There are many good reasons for growers to invest in soil fertility mapping: nutrient management planning, land use planning, planting decisions, etc. SoilSerdem’s technology will utilize robust machine-learning tools with remotely sensed data to significantly increase the quality of soil data presented to the end-users in terms of accuracy and resolution. To meet the projected global food demand by 2050, production must be increased by 60-70%. This innovation will be a cornerstone to efficient farming of the future.

During the I-Corps customer discovery process (105 interviews), we mapped the relationship between the end-users (growers), influencers (university extension and agronomic consultants), and vendors (retailers) in the commercial agriculture space. Growers working over 100 acres request soil maps from agronomists to inform their nutrient management planning. The main reason that growers prefer to work with agronomists is that they trust agronomists - as an independent information broker - for nutrient management recommendations more than retailers. The best way to reach out to potential customers is by attending trade shows (e.g., Farm Progress Show and Husker Harvest Days) and extension conferences. The team established a cursory network across the USA during this program.
